lines.text: What kind of music do you play?
Anything they ask me to, and then I play ragtime.
I read music so good, white folks think I'm fakin' it.
I design fireworks. That's my job.
[the black anarchists laugh in derision]
. I can make bombs.
[They stop laughing and take him seriously]
Nobody's intimidating me, Mister. You just don't know what you're getting yourself into, and I'm trying to keep your nose clean. Now, would you be a good boy and just get along.?
I want my car cleaned!
Clean it then, damn you! Clean it and go!
I want the man who did it to clean it!

All right, all right, let me pit it this way. I can arrest you for blocking a public service exit, for creating a public nuisance, and about ten other things I ain't gonna mention. Now, am I making myself clear?
Yes.
Good.
Officer, I still want my car cleaned.
Oh, for Christ's sake! Ain't you got any sense in your head? I'm trying to help you! You leave me no choice.
I'm sorry.
You're under arrest!

[refering to the anarchists in the library]
Well, Mr. Elliot, why don't you go in and have a word with them?
I beg your pardon?
Just explain the value of the library, see what they want, that sort of thing.

That hardly seems like the appropriate response, Mr. Waldo, and if you're making a joke at my expense, I assure you there's nothing amusing about my responsibilities as the curator of Mr. Morgan's library.
Mr. Elliot, as long as those guys are in there, you're not curator of anything!

[to Walker in the library]
What you have done here has set our race back a distance I can't measure.

[while praying]
Lord, why did you fill me with such rage?

[praying]
Lord, I'd hoped I'd have the courage to know what I should do now. You must see how sick at heart I've been... and how I've performed this thing with little appetite.
[sobbing]
I'd hoped... you'd reveal to me along the way why you put such a rage in my heart.
[a brief pause]
Tell me what to do now!
[another beat]
Please.
[sighs]
God, tell me what to do.

[Coalhouse tries to sue for his car being damaged]
Well, what's your financial situation like?

[sighs]
I have a little laid by. I planned to use it on my wedding, but I guess it'll have to wait.

Hmm. Mr. Walker, let me give you some advice. You spend the money on your wedding. Build yourself a home and a family where you can find some comfort. And just forget that some damn white man caused you offense.
And that's your advice?
That's my advice, and I pray you take it to heart.
Just forget it? Is that it?
I've spent my whole life forgetting. You're a young man. You better start learning now.
Learning what? How to be a nigger?

[after a pause]
Mr. Walker, I'll thank you to leave. I have some charity cases you know nothing of. I got clients with real problems - starvation, illness, dispossession. Yes, I want justice for our people. Yes, I do. I want it so bad, I can taste it. If you think I'll go to Westchester County pleading on the behalf of a colored man that somebody dirtied his fancy car, you are very much mistaken. Now, please, you take this and leave my office.
[Gives Coalhouse papers]
That library over there is worth millions and people keep telling me you're a piece of slime.
This little piggy went wee weee wee wee all the way to the bank.

[about Coalhouse]
He say one thing, and then he say another thing. And he make it all sound so good. It ain't nuthin' but talk, Ma'am. It ain't nuthin' but talk!
Where is J. P. Morgan?
Oh, he's on an expedition down the Nile... in Egypt.
Hmmm... Lucky him!
[Looks at the Captain]
Yes, sir!
And contact some colored big shots to talk to us in case we need to negotiate.
Very good, sir. Anything else?
Yeah, he said something about a car and a fire chief.
Conklin. Willie Conklin.
Get him. I want to meet him.
Sir, that number doesn't answer. What do you want me to do?

[after thinking about it for several moments]
Get me some coffee and a roll.
[Coalhouse has just learned that his friends have safely escaped]

[trepidatiously]
Well, shouldn't we... uh... tell them... that we're... we're coming?

[calmly]
Yeah. You go on ahead. Tell 'em I'll be right out.

[hesitates]
Well...
Just go on. I'll be with you.

[still hesitates]
Don't...?

[firmly]
Go.

[stammering]
Don't you think it would be... a better idea if we...?

[exploding]
GET THE HELL OUT OF HERE! Don't you understand ANYTHING, white man?
[terrified, rushes out of the library]
